review_title: Overall a great place to work.
pros: The health insurance benefits are second to none.  It is probably one of the primary reasons i have not looked elsewhere. The hospital really tries to make sure that we are not just a number but since there are 2800 of us it can be difficult.  I work for an AWESOME Director.  They have allowed me to spread my wings.  She has even pushed me out of the nest to encourage me to soar.  They are consistently fair, equal and helpful.  If I give my director the information they need to make a decision, I will usually get the answer I am looking for.
cons: We get to play the parking game everyday!  Yes our parking is free and most of us abide by the parking rules.  Most of us call the security in the parking garage the "parking Nazi's."  Do not continue to make the good employees pay for the behavior of the bad employees.  Some of the managers have been in their position for a long time and they may not be the best suited for the job with the current changes in health care.  If the managers do not keep up on changes how will they be able to know what their staff is doing and whether they are doing it correctly.

pros: great benefits, many opportunities to grow or move

pros: there is always work to be done

pros: Intelligent nursing staff. Interested in evidenced based medicine.
cons: Upper administration failure to see big picture of all areas other than what they come from. HR not supportive when there is a serious concern. Would rather coach out healthcare professional with known addictions than to actually provide information to get them help. Those people just end up at other area facilities and are a risk to others. Several director level new hires not given proper support and mentoring, All let go during their first 90 days. At some point they need to realize it’s not the new hires fault and look at the lack of support for new managers.

review_title: Good strong company, a bit hard to get ahead

new software training seemed to be an afterthought

review_title: Supportive management; skilled and caring staff
pros: You will hear over and over again from the staff that they love working at Valley Medical Center because the management is supportive, the benefits are great and particularly because colleagues feel like family. If you layer on a highly skilled clinical staff, beautiful facility and administrators who truly care about their staff and the patients, and an affiliation with UW Medicine, a world-class teaching and research hospital - it's hard to find a job in a healthcare facility that's much better.
cons: We have myriad problems with our five member Board of Commissioners; the majority are more focused on politics than ensuring quality patient care. Thankfully the Administration have their priorities straight.

job_title: Middle Management in East Renton Highlands, WA
pros: The medical providers are universally skilled, dedicated, and professional.
cons: Callous, inept senior office administrators who create a toxic culture that contributes to inefficiency, petty and harmful staff behavior, immature backstabbing, and roguish attitude.

job_title: Clinical Applications Analyst in Renton, WA
pros: They pride themselves on diversity and employee recognition, and fir a karge medical center htat's a bit unusual. They are very good to their employees in most instances.  I think that the management cares, although it is hard to hear from, or see the CEO or very upper management.  They are going through some growing pangs, but seem to have it well in hand.  They also seem to be havingt some money problems due to the economy, but probably are affected less by it that many other companies.
cons: Some new management especialy in IT department.  They are good but need some time to fix some longstanding items.

review_title: I used to be impressed with Valley, but they’ve shown us that money rules over patient safety and satisfaction.
pros: Competitive pay and decent health insurance. Free and ample parking available for employees. Great hospitalists and specialists. Values the use of increased technology in interdisciplinary communications.
cons: Valley regularly violates union contract. Management prioritizes the bottom line over patient and employee safety. Staffing ratios and poor work flows on the units have seen real and dangerous consequences for patients and each RN licensure is jeopardized. RNs are pressured to attest to taking their breaks when they have not. Best take your license to another organization that values your input and worth.

review_title: Incompetent, rude and constant inter-office bickering
pros: The pay and benefits were okay.  I've heard many positive reviews of other clinics within Valley Medical Center.
cons: This deals with the Fairwood Primary Care clinic. Telephone hold times were a minimum of ten minutes for patients, lines were long even with an open receptionist (we were told to "just answer the phone, don't check in any patients), there was constant inter-office bickering and endless politics, too many HIPAA violations to count and the staff I worked with were nothing but rude and condescending to both each other and the patients.  It was nearly impossible to learn the job because different people kept trying to tell new hires to do things different ways.  No set systems, no control.  Just an awful place to work.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Renton, WA
pros:
Benefits are excellent. Fully vested after 7 years, 403(b), generous opportunity to accrue vacation, catastrophic sick in addition to regular sick. Full medical/dental with only .6 FTE (24 hrs/wk). Full-time FTEs are allowed one dependent with full benefits also. 

Parking is free. Beats working at a big hospital in downtown Seattle and paying a ridiculous amount for parking.

VMC employees generally stay for great lengths of time. It's not unusual to see employees stay for 5,10,25 years.

If you don't like one department, or grow tired of it, there's opportunity to transfer into the same position somewhere else within the hospital.
cons:
Job satisfaction obviously varies between departments and positions. PSR positions are not difficult responsibilities, yet there is a vast learning and capability curve since PSR age demographics range from early 20s to mid 50s. Almost always female. So if your technical and multi-tasking abilities are on point, you'll excel at PSR work, and possibly become frustrated with your peers who aren't quite up-to-date with their computer skills or who have difficulty prioritizing. Yet they will make more than you because they've been there for over a decade.

Management is not transparent. Employees are treated on a need-to-know basis. Productivity and budget are priorities, as they should be, but performing well and generating revenue is driven more out of fear of being reprimanded or laid-off rather than pride in work.

The hospital is struggling financially, yet constantly mails out announcements and promotions about how great the hospital is, using expensive glossy colored paper. Employees don't care about that, they'd rather that administration utilizes more eco-friendly and cost-effective way to deliver relevant communications.

job_title: Patient Resource Representative in Renton, WA
pros: No dress code, can wear jeans
cons: If you want to be treated like a kindergartner, never hear positive feedback, be constantly watched and experience complete disrespect then this is the place for you!  High turnover, always short staffed and if you have a voice they shut you up immediately.  This place will destroy your self esteem, no one is ever good enough.  Only get to park on site every other month and soon every 2 months.

pros: Beautiful facility, nice benefits for healthcare insurance, handy to have the gym with the hospital for workout.
cons: This is a union environment.  Medical directors have a political force in the facility (a plus and minus) the staff can seem nice on the outside but do covert snipes.  I believe the culture has hidden agendas that are not easy to read,

pros: Patient care by psychiatrists and psychotherapist.
cons: Was a therapist here for a short time but don't miss it.  Management of clinic seems great in terms of making sure the doctors and front office staff are REALLY happy. However, it is rough for therapists. There is gossip and favorites.  Feels like you have to watch your step.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Renton, WA
pros: Benefits, wages, had a great place to work. Loved my coworkers. Worked as a team which was a plus. We knew what needed to be done and got it done
cons: Inept Management. Not having a clue as to what you even do. We run the place not them. When management shows up tornado. Upper management doesnt feel we deserve the pay we get for running the clinic!

review_title: Patient Resource Center shows the changing roles at VMC

pros:
They let interns do a lot of different things at Valley. First 2 years you generally do tech functions such as: refilling pyxis machines, triaging information from phone calls, preparing medications for patients, compounding, compounding intravenous drugs, compounding chemotherapy drugs. 

Your 3rd and 4th year you get to learn how to do order entry and follow patients on antibiotic therapy, pain management, TPN, and anticoagulation.
cons: You are an intern, anything goes wrong, the blame is put onto you.

pros: sit stand desks, quiet work environment, pay, epic system, IT specialist that will tweak epic to work more for you.
cons: random layoffs, pushed to do more than the productivity listed in union contract, the cash goal increases every month, no reward for bringing in more money, hardly any flexibility for schedule, cant work from home
